address: 11611 East Branch Parkway, San Ramon, CA 94583
philosophyApproach: Boy-run and active troop in accordance with Scouting tradition. Comprehensive advancement program for new scouts (Webelos) designed to get them to First Class rank quickly.
activityFrequency: Several per month, approximately 35 outings per year
monthlyOutings: At least one overnight camp per month plus day trips
regularActivities: Camping overnights, day trips, bike rides, ski trips, snow camping, backpacking, kayaking, midnight broomball, service projects (Scouting for Food)

specializedPrograms.cycling: Mid-August to October: 8-10 rides (10/15/25 miles) leading to 50-mile final ride. Golden Gate Bridge ride is a highlight. Earns Cycling Merit Badge.
specializedPrograms.backpacking: Over 10 practice hikes (10-20 miles, some overnight) leading to either 50-mile backpacking trip or Philmont
specializedPrograms.snowCamping: 1-2 mile snowshoe hike, build snow shelters (cave, igloo, hop house), camp overnight in snow shelter without tent

highAdventure: Philmont Scout Ranch (2015, 2017, 2019, 2021, 2025) with multiple treks per year, 50-mile backpacking in alternate years
summerCamps: Different camp every year. Past: Wolfeboro (2015, 2021), Emerald Bay (2019), Royaneh, Wente, Oljato, Cherry Valley, Chawanakee
leadershipStructure: Scoutmaster: Sathish Nayak. First Wednesday of each month is Patrol Leader's Council (PLC) for elected troop leaders. Scoutmaster conferences for Tenderfoot/Second Class/First Class at regular meetings.

parentInvolvement.details: $400 deposit at registration, refundable to scout account after 12 volunteer hours. Unclaimed funds: 60% to Friends of Scouting, 40% to Troop. All parents must complete YPT (Youth Protection Training) and IOLS for overnight camps.

reputation: One of the fastest growing troops in Meridian District. Named to honor Daniel Carter Beard (6/21/1850), one of founders of American Scouting. Among the most active troops in Bay Area for outings and high adventure.
notes: Founded 2012 to serve Windemere Ranch area. Strongest high adventure program with multiple Philmont treks per year. Very active with ~35 outings annually. Comprehensive cycling and backpacking programs.

address: 6400 Main Branch Road, San Ramon, CA 94582
philosophyApproach: One of the most active and respected units in the area. Dedicated to development of character, citizenship, physical and mental fitness. Strive to provide a scouting experience filled with variety and diversity. Engaged scouts in the program and journey, not the end result. Consistently receives the Quality Unit Award.
activityFrequency: Extremely active calendar with comprehensive outdoor program
monthlyOutings: Regular monthly outdoor activities plus special events like broomball on ice, curling, picnics, laser tag, escape rooms, K1 racing
regularActivities: Camping, backpacking, conservation projects, merit badges, Camporee, Trooporee (troop camporee), new scout hikes, service projects

specializedPrograms.highAdventure: Philmont 2024 (40-50 miles, 9-day trek with blacksmithing, muzzle-loading, summiting Baldy Mountain at 12,441 feet); Northern Tier 2024 (8-day trek, 75 miles by canoe in Canadian Crownlands with portaging, earned 75 Miler award)
specializedPrograms.summerCampSpecialties: Wolfeboro annual tradition with Sourdough program, rockers (special awards), Pioneer status for multi-year attendees
specializedPrograms.newScoutProgram: Comprehensive first year program with Patrol Leaders, Troop Guides, and dedicated ASMs. Special new scout hikes and advancement support during PLC meetings

highAdventure: Philmont 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025 (multiple crews); Northern Tier 2024 (first crew); all four BSA High Adventure bases available
summerCamps: Two camps every year. Wolfeboro (annual - 2023, 2024, 2025), Camp Cherry Valley Catalina Island (2023), Royaneh (2024 - cabins, ATV program, Eagle-required merit badges, horseback riding)
leadershipStructure: Scoutmaster: Anand Ranganathan (Wood Badge, Wilderness First Aid, CPR/AED certified, Philmont Leader 2022-2023). Multiple ASMs organized by patrol. Active Eagle Advisors. Parent meetings every two months on 2nd Monday.

parentInvolvement.details: Parent engagement strongly encouraged. Parent meetings bimonthly. Volunteer opportunities for merit badge counselors, ASMs, Eagle advisors, and activity leaders.

adultLeaders: 35+ ASMs organized by patrol, multiple Eagle Advisors, Wood Badge trained leaders
reputation: One of the most active and respected troops in the area. Consistently receives Quality Unit Award. 100+ Eagle Scouts since 1988 (3-15 Eagles per year recently). Strong high adventure tradition with annual Philmont crews. First troop to document Northern Tier experience for future crews.
notes: Extremely active with comprehensive outdoor program. Annual Wolfeboro tradition. Recent high adventure: Philmont 2024, Northern Tier 2024. Unique Trooporee event (troop's camporee). Strong new scout support program. Patrol-based leadership structure.

address: 9015 S. Gale Ridge Road, San Ramon, CA 94582
philosophyApproach: First troop in San Ramon (chartered 1962). Traditional boy-led troop centered around 3 basic aims of Scouting: Character Development, Citizenship Training, Mental and Physical Fitness. Program centered around outdoor activities demonstrating 'Prepared for Life' philosophy. Every scout has ample opportunity to learn and practice leadership skills. Most Eagle Scouts continue active participation beyond 18th birthday.
activityFrequency: Weekly meetings plus at least one major outdoor activity per month
monthlyOutings: At least one major outdoor activity monthly, year-round program
regularActivities: Overnight campouts, snow camping, ski trips, day hikes, bicycling, District Camporee, service projects. Weekly meetings blend activity planning, advancement, games, and camaraderie.

specializedPrograms.boyLedEmphasis: Program planning and leadership provided by Scouts under guidance of Scoutmaster and ASMs. Supports Scouts in all ranks with active Eagle Scout participation.
specializedPrograms.highAdventure: Annual High Adventure Backpacking Outings. Philmont 2021 (7-day, 30-mile trek). Sea Base 2005 (Florida). British Columbia canoe trek 2003 (72-mile at Bowron Lake Provincial Park).
specializedPrograms.internationalExperience: Camp Pupukea Hawaii 2014 (2nd Scout Camp of year)

highAdventure: Philmont 2021 (7-day, 30-mile); Sea Base 2005; British Columbia 2003 (72-mile canoe trek); annual High Adventure Backpacking
summerCamps: Camp Wolfeboro (annual tradition), Camp Pupukea Hawaii (2014). Year-round program with summer-time meetings since 2007.
leadershipStructure: Scoutmaster: James W. Ringener (current, returned 2022); Fil de Cal (2021-2022, Wood Badge, NYLT, HAT Backpacking, L.E.A.D., Unit Commissioner). Assistant Scoutmasters and Troop Committee with blend of experienced and new adults. All trips supervised by BSA-trained leaders.

parentInvolvement.details: Most successful Scouts are supported by their families. Troop activities require active support of all troop families. Adult leadership includes uniformed leaders and Troop Committee members.

dues: $350 annual (prorated based on join date), $25 one-time fee if new to scouting. Webelos pay $200 (prorated) as BSA+Council fee paid by Cub Scout packs.
adultLeaders: Blend of experienced and new adults among uniformed leaders and Troop Committee
reputation: First troop in San Ramon (chartered November 1962). Rich 60+ year history - originally Troop 1 in Walnut Creek (1934-1951), then Troop 201 Walnut Creek (1951-1962), relocated to San Ramon 1962. 65+ Eagle Scouts since 1966. Commemorative flag pole at Camp Wolfeboro for Eagle Scout Michael Grey (Vietnam War). 50th San Ramon anniversary celebrated 2012. Moved to current Canyon Creek location 2007 enabling year-round program.
notes: First and oldest troop in San Ramon with deep tradition. Traditional boy-led program. Year-round meetings including summer. Strong Eagle Scout legacy with most continuing beyond age 18. Virtual programming pioneer during COVID-19 (led Meridian District Virtual Camporee 2020).

charteredOrg: Kiwanis Club of San Ramon Valley
philosophyApproach: Boy-run troop where scouts plan and carry out activities with adults facilitating. Strong emphasis on youth leadership training and development through experience. Adults encourage, guide, ensure safety but let scouts lead and learn from mistakes.
activityFrequency: Year-round weekly meetings (except late Nov/Dec), monthly camping/outdoor activities, multiple summer camps, high adventure trips
monthlyOutings: Monthly camping, backpacking, or outdoor activities. No break in summer.
regularActivities: Monthly camping/backpacking, service projects (Scouting for Food, beach/creek cleanups, Memorial Day flag planting, 9/11 ceremony), Kiwanis 4th of July Parade support, conservation projects, merit badge sessions, patrol competitions, flag ceremonies

specializedPrograms.cycling: Extensive cycling program with regular 10-25+ mile rides
specializedPrograms.backpacking: Introduction to backpacking, beginner courses, regular backpacking trips (Black Diamond Mines, Redwood Regional, Mt. Diablo)
specializedPrograms.snowCamping: Introduction to snow camping program at Carson Pass/Lake Tahoe
specializedPrograms.climbing: Rock climbing sessions at The Rock and Diablo Rock Gym, climbing merit badge opportunities
specializedPrograms.highAdventure: Regular Philmont treks, plans for Northern Tier and other high adventure bases
specializedPrograms.shooting: Archery (USA Archery Level II instructors on staff), rifle shooting, marksmanship weekends at Camp Tamarancho
specializedPrograms.pioneering: COPE courses, rappelling, team building activities

highAdventure: Philmont (multiple crews), Northern Tier, planning for Sea Base and other BSA high adventure bases. Strong high adventure tradition.
summerCamps: Rotates between multiple camps: Camp Chawanakee (2024), Camp Royaneh (2025), Camp Wente (2021), Camp Wolfeboro (past years). Week-long resident summer camps with 40+ merit badge options.
leadershipStructure: Highly structured youth leadership with elected SPL (69 SPLs since 1985), appointed ASPLs, patrol leaders, and 15+ specialized positions (Quartermaster, Scribe, Historian, Librarian, Webmaster, Instructors, Troop Guides, OA Rep, Den Chiefs, etc.). Leadership training required. 6-month terms with goal-setting and accountability.

parentInvolvement.structure: All parents automatic Troop Committee members. Bi-monthly parent meetings (1st Tuesday). Parents encouraged as drivers (required 2+ trips/year), merit badge counselors, committee leaders, ASMs. Strong parent volunteer culture.
parentInvolvement.requirements: Provide transportation for at least 2 outdoor activities per year. Summer camp drop-off/pick-up as needed.

eagleScoutRetention: Very high - most Eagles remain active through age 18. Strong tradition of continued involvement. Unit College Scouter Reserves program for Eagles in college.
reputation: Established 1985 in Danville. 149 Eagle Scouts (as of Sept 2025). Co-founded by George H. Coughlin II (Silver Beaver 2007). Multiple Silver Beaver recipients (Ray Chan 2014, Kent Screechfield 2015, Sue Oki 2008). Known for exemplary boy-run program with scouts making decisions and learning from experience. Strong leadership development pipeline. Very structured with detailed processes, training, and accountability. Active in community service including Kiwanis partnership. Quality Unit Awards.
uniqueSellingPoints:
• 149 Eagle Scouts over 40 years (3.7/year average)
• Exceptional youth leadership training structure with 15+ specialized positions
• Year-round programming (no summer break)
• Extensive specialized programs (cycling, backpacking, snow camping, climbing, shooting sports)
• Multiple adult leaders with advanced certifications (USA Archery Level II, NRA instructors, Wilderness First Aid, Wood Badge)
• Strong high adventure tradition with regular Philmont crews
• Comprehensive equipment program with dedicated Quartermasters
• Active merit badge counselor network within troop
• 40-year tradition of boy-run scouting
• Strong Kiwanis partnership since founding
dues: $150 initial joining fee ($130 if crossing from Cubs - includes handbook, neckerchief, BSA registration). $150 annual membership (December) includes re-registration, Boys' Life, insurance, equipment maintenance. $200 FOS contribution requested (March). Popcorn sales go to Scout accounts for trips/equipment.
contactMore:
recruiting@troop805.org
Patrick Kuzmickas (Scoutmaster): pnkuzmickas@gmail.com
Andy Szeto (Committee Chair): cc@troop805.org
adultLeaders: Scoutmaster: Patrick Kuzmickas (Eagle Scout, USA Archery Level II). 25+ ASMs including multiple Eagle Scouts, Wood Badge trained leaders, specialized instructors (USA Archery Level II, NRA Rifle, Wilderness First Aid, CERT trained). Scoutmaster Emeriti: Ray Chan (Silver Beaver 2014, VP GGAC Program), George Coughlin II (Silver Beaver 2007, Co-founder), Neal Matsunaga (Eagle), Kent Screechfield (Silver Beaver 2015, Charter Org Rep), Sue Oki (Silver Beaver 2008, District Commissioner). Large active committee with 30+ volunteer positions.
notes: True boy-run troop since 1985. Scouts plan and lead meetings, activities, and outings with adult facilitation focused on safety and mentoring. Extensive youth leadership development system with structured accountability. Adults selected by Committee. Strong outdoor program year-round including specialized activities (cycling, backpacking, snow camping, climbing, shooting). 149 Eagles demonstrates sustained excellence. Multiple summer camp options. High adventure tradition. Deep community service commitment through Kiwanis partnership. Equipment policy teaches responsibility. Weekly meetings year-round (except holidays). Bi-monthly parent meetings. Very detailed processes and training for all roles. Strong emphasis on Scout Oath, Law, and outdoor ethics.

address: 3000 Pine Valley Road, San Ramon, CA 94583
philosophyApproach: Boy-run troop operating by patrol method, PLC plans activities with Scoutmaster & Committee oversight
activityFrequency: Monthly outdoor activities plus weekly meetings, 2 summer camps annually
monthlyOutings: At least one outdoor activity per month including camping, hiking, backpacking
regularActivities: Camping, hiking, backpacking, whitewater rafting, cycling, skiing/snowboarding, kayaking, winter camping, Scout-O orienteering, beach outings

specializedPrograms.backpacking: Multiple troop-led backpacking trips throughout year for beginners and advanced
specializedPrograms.eagleMentoring: Eagle Scout Advisors mentor Life Scouts through Eagle process

highAdventure: Philmont (2023, 2025), Northern Tier (2023), Florida Sea Base (2024, 2025), Summit Bechtel Reserve (2022, 2026 planned), Yosemite backcountry week. Some scouts earned Grand Slam of High Adventure
highAdventureShort: Philmont (2025), Northern Tier (2023), Sea Base (2025), Summit (2022)
summerCamps: Camp Wolfeboro every June, plus one other 6-day resident camp each July (2025: Camp Royaneh)
leadershipStructure: Boy-led with Patrol Leaders' Council (PLC). SPL: Evan Li. 7 active patrols. Leadership positions rotate June-November

parentInvolvement.description: Parents help with special projects, monthly committee meetings. Core group of leaders but always need new parents

eagleScoutRetention: 116 Eagle Scouts from 1989-2025 (2.9 Eagles/year average over 40+ years)
reputation: Active troop with 40+ year tradition. Multiple Wolfeboro Pioneers among leadership. 9 of 16 adult leaders are Wood Badge alumni. Strong high adventure program with Grand Slam achievers
adultLeaders: Scoutmaster: Vijay Gadad. 16 direct-contact adult leaders (9 Wood Badge Alumni), 9 Executive Committee members. Multiple Wolfeboro Pioneers
notes: Very active troop with extensive outdoor program including monthly backpacking trips. Summer meetings at Boone Acres Park (June-July). Service: Scouting for Food, 9/11 ceremonies, coastal cleanup, Pine Valley MS support. Fundraising: Evergreen wreath sale, Christmas tree recycling (scouts keep large percentage for camp costs). Courts of Honor twice yearly

address: 19001 San Ramon Valley Blvd, San Ramon, CA 94583
philosophyApproach: Boy Scouts plan, prepare and execute their own program. Adults facilitate the program the scouts have planned. Affiliated with Ship 1776 Sea Scout crew
activityFrequency: Weekly meetings during school year, monthly campouts, annual summer camp
monthlyOutings: Scout-planned monthly outings including Mt Diablo Campout, Archery Camp Out, Sunset State Beach, Klondike Derby, Trail Bike Rides
regularActivities: Camping, hiking, backpacking, archery, biking, sailing, power boating through Ship 1776 affiliation

specializedPrograms.seaScouting: Affiliated with Ship 1776 for sailing and power boating activities
specializedPrograms.webelosOutreach: Aquanaut (August water safety at Cal High Pool), Zombie First Aid (October), Pizza Hike (Fall on Shady Slope Trail)

highAdventure: Contact troop for high adventure opportunities
summerCamps: Camp Marin Sierra (2024). Summer meetings at Cal High Pool (June-July)
leadershipStructure: Scout-led program. First Friday of each month is PLC meeting where scout leaders plan monthly meetings

parentInvolvement.description: Each family expected to volunteer 10 hours per year

eagleScoutRetention: 15 Eagles in last 5 years (3 Eagles/year average)
reputation: Unique Sea Scout affiliation offering both land and water activities. Friday meetings provide scheduling flexibility. Strong Webelos outreach program
adultLeaders: Scoutmaster: Ken Nicholson (Founding SM since April 2000, also Founding Skipper of Ship 1776). 7 Assistant Scoutmasters, 7 Committee members with specialized roles (Eagle Coordinator, Advancement Coordinator, Summer Camp Coordinator, etc.)
notes: Friday meetings (unique scheduling). Summer meetings at Cal High Pool. Affiliated with Ship 1776 for sailing/boating. Strong Webelos outreach. Service: Scouting for Food, Pleasanton Tree Planting, Veterans Parade. Yacht decoration and Lighted Yacht Parade events

charteredOrg: Kiwanis Club of San Ramon Valley
philosophyApproach: Boy-Led troop run by Scouts, not adults. Scouts decide on and plan activities. Adults advise and coach in the background to develop maturity and leadership skills
activityFrequency: Weekly meetings with skill building, at least one camping/backpacking trip per month
monthlyOutings: 12+ campouts/year including everything from Camporee to car camping to snow camping to week-long wilderness treks
regularActivities: Camping, backpacking, hiking, rafting, canoeing, archery, rifle/shotgun shooting, rock climbing, ziplining, mountain biking, whitewater rafting, midnight broomball, urban hikes, SF Giants Day

specializedPrograms.firstYearProgram: Comprehensive 'First Year' program designed to help scouts learn, achieve and advance. Focus on fun, new skills, and outdoor experience
specializedPrograms.catalinaCamp: Camp Emerald Bay on Catalina Island (usually every other summer - odd years) for 2nd year+ scouts with water and boating merit badge opportunities
specializedPrograms.shooting: Rifle, shotgun, archery programs with certified instructors
specializedPrograms.patrolSystem: Two patrols at each age level, eight scouts per patrol for manageable boy-led structure

highAdventure: Philmont, Northern Tier, Whitney, Lost Coast. Week-long wilderness treks with backpacks only or transport by canoe
highAdventureShort: Philmont, Northern Tier, Whitney, Lost Coast
summerCamps: Variety of summer camps: Chawanakee, Wente, Camp Emerald Bay (Catalina Island). Rotates locations annually
leadershipStructure: Scout-run program with Patrol Leadership Council (PLC) designing meetings and activities. PLC meets first Monday of month (6-7 PM). Troop Leadership Council (TLC) meets 3rd Monday

parentInvolvement.description: Parents help support both Scout and Troop. Many volunteer opportunities from trained adult leaders to non-training roles. Vitally important for troop health

eagleScoutRetention: 225+ Eagle Scouts since 1969 (4.0 Eagles/year average over 56 years). Proud tradition of Eagle achievement
reputation: "Danville Pride" Since 1969 - Oldest Boy Scout Troop in Danville. Well established with highly valued traditions. Reputation for leadership in Council. 56 years of excellence
dues: $220/year ($50 supports troop, $170 stays in scout's account for activities). New scouts receive: BSA Handbook, Troop 815 neckerchief & slide, Class B t-shirt, water bottle, patch
contactMore: Jenn Bill (Recruiting Chair): (925)-735-8260, info@troop815.net; Joe Moss (Scoutmaster): (501) 282-8250, Scoutmaster@troop815.net
adultLeaders: Scoutmaster: Joe Moss. 30+ trained adult leaders. Adults serve in background as advisors and coaches. 'Two Deep' leadership always practiced. Extensive network for coaching, advising, counseling and troubleshooting
notes: Oldest troop in Danville (56 years). Recruiting policy maintains manageable size for scout-run operation. Class A uniform required for meetings, flag ceremonies, public service. Summer meetings at Osage Station Park for outdoor activities (June-August). Service: Scouting for Food, Sandbag Brigade. Weekend trips: Pinnacles, Angel Island, Point Reyes. Scout Orienteering, Night Hikes
